title: Object-Graphs for Context-Aware Category Discovery

author: Yong Jae Lee, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Texas at Austin

So the main motivation of our work is to perform unsupervised category learning, where the system takes as input an unlabeled image collection, compute similarities between the images or regions and groups them to discover categories.
Unsupervised category discovery is appealing for several reasons.
First, it can reveal structure in large image collections and second it can greatly reduce annotation time and effort when compared to supervised learning methods.

So existing work can largely be divided into two groups.

The first uses topic models such as probabilistic latent semantic analysis or latent directly allocation, and the second performs a hard partitioning of the image data using spectral clustering or affinity propagation.
While recent work has shown great progress, there are several limitations.
Existing methods rely only on appearance information.
Treating category discovery as an appearance grouping problem.

So the main contributions of our work is the idea of context aware category discovery.

Note that our setting is different from the usual semi supervised learning scenario and semi supervised learning.
There are labeled and unlabeled points, but all all points are assumed to belong to the same set of categories.
In our setting, we have familiar and unfamiliar categories and the the object level context from the familiar categories are used to discover the unfamiliar categories.
So to overview the approach, we first learn category models on some classes.
Then, given an unlabeled image collection for each image.
We detect instances that belong to a familiar category.
And label the remaining regions as unknown.

Then for each unknown reason, we describe its object level context via our object graph descriptor, and finally we discover categories by grouping reasons that have similar appearance and similar content.
We first train SVM classifiers on a set of categories using color, texture and shape features.
In our running example, the known categories are tree building, Sky Ann Rd.
Given an unlabeled pool of novel images, we compute multiple segmentations.
This is to increase the chance that each object in the image will have a corresponding segment somewhere in the pool of multiple segmentations.

Then for each segment in the pool of multiple segmentations, we run our familiar category classifiers to compute posterior probabilities which indicate the likelihood that a region belongs to a familiar category.
We then compute entropy given the posterior distributions.

So those reasons that are likely to belong to a familiar category, such as the tree building and Rd regions will have more peakier distributions, which will lead to low entropy while those that are unfamiliar, such as the car region, will have more evenly distributed posteriors which will produce high entropy.
So we sort all the regions based on the entropy scores and take those with the highest scores to be unknown.
Novelty detection has largely been ignored in computer vision for object recognition and has not been considered for category discovery.
